It is thus quite conceivable that the cosmic fluid can be regarded as a dark energy fluid (the region $-1<w<-1/3$ is called the quintessence region, while $w<-1$ is the phantom region). Observing that the dark energy fraction  is so dominant, about $70\%$, it has been common to assume the cosmic fluid to be a one-component fluid.

For some years  it has been known that if the cosmic fluid starts out from some value of $w$ lying in the phantom region, it will encounter some form of singularity in the remote future. The most dramatic event is called the big rip, in which the fluid enters into a singularity after a finite time $t_s$ given by \cite{caldwell03,nojiri03,nojiri04}

Again referring to the Planck data, Table 4 in \citep{ade15}, we have  $\Omega_{\Lambda}=0.6911\pm 0.0062$, $\Omega_{0\rm m}=0.3089\pm 0.0062$, when $68\%$ intervals are considered. Other extensions to the basic model would include the present relative density of radiation $\Omega_{0\rm r}$, which again is neglected in the present paper.\\

 As a second generalization we will take into account the bulk viscosity of the cosmic fluid. As is known, there exists also a second viscosity coefficient, the shear viscosity, to be considered in the general case when one works to the first order deviations from thermal equilibrium.   The shear
 coefficient is  of particular importance when dealing with
flow near solid surfaces, but it can  be crucial also under
boundary-free conditions such as in isotropic turbulence (for cosmological applications, cf. Refs.~\cite{brevik12,brevik11a}).  When the fluid is spatially isotropic, the shear viscosity is usually left out, and we will make the same assumption here. Then only the
bulk viscosity coefficient, called $\zeta$, remains in the fluid's energy-momentum tensor. It is notable that in recent years it has become quite common to include  viscous aspects of the cosmic fluid (readers interested in  general accounts of viscous cosmology under various circumstances may consult, for instance, Refs.~\cite{weinberg71,weinberg72,zimdahl96,BrevikGron13,bamba15}).

We will make the following ansatz for the bulk viscosity:

where $\lambda \geq 0$, and $\zeta_0$ is the present viscosity. The above ansatz, for some power of $\lambda$, has been used throughout the literature, both for the early universe \citep{murphy73, barrow86, li10, campo07}  and for the later universe ~\citep{Gorbunova, brevik06, nojiri05a, paolis10, Frontiers, cardenas15}. The two most actual values for $\lambda$ are $\lambda=\frac{1}{2}$ whereby $\zeta \propto \theta \propto \sqrt \rho$, and $\lambda=1$ whereby $\zeta \propto \theta^2\propto \rho$. Again considering the case of a dark fluid, we see that Eq.~(\ref{6}) predicts $\zeta \rightarrow \infty$ near the big rip where $\theta \rightarrow \infty$. In some of the previous literature mentioned above, both Eq. (\ref{6}) and Eq. (\ref{5}) are assumed at the same time, with $\gamma-1 =\lambda$. As mentioned,  Eq.~(\ref{5}) is however not assumed in the present work; for clarity we take $w=-1+\alpha$ throughout. \\

When attempting to give a reliable description of the evolution of the late universe, one is  confronted with the following problem: what can be said about the values of the present-day viscosity $\zeta_0$, and the coefficient $\beta$? To get information about this one has to take into account observations involving  the earlier
 universe. And this will be our main topic in the following sections. In particular, we will make use of the recent analysis of Wang and Meng \cite{wang14},  based upon an analysis of a number of recent observations. From this, we will be able  to estimate the values of $\beta$ and $\zeta_0$. Especially the order of magnitude for $\zeta_0$ is of interest, as little seems to be known about this quantity from before.

 It is to be borne in mind that the inclusion of a bulk viscosity is done only on a phenomenological basis. There might be fundamental reasons for its presence, but such reasons are to our knowledge not known. From an analogy with standard hydrodynamics a phenomenological approach  is obviously  natural.

\bigskip

Our outline is the following:

 In the next section, a review is given of the methods and results in Ref.~\citep{wang14}. With this paper as background, we will see the need for a more  general solution, which is worked out.

 Section  III contains a central part of our work, as general bulk-viscous solutions are presented for $\zeta(z)$ ($z$ being the redshift) and $\zeta(\rho)$. We justify our approach and present the underlying assumptions. The section contains also some simple best-fit regressions for three different models for the bulk viscosity.

 Section IV draws lines to previous works and discusses the results. The model where $\zeta \propto \sqrt \rho$, and the magnitude of the viscosity suggested so far in the literature, is considered.

 Finally, on the basis of the obtained value for the viscosity, we return in the final section to the late universe. In particular, we estimate the time needed to run into the big rip singularity.

This assumption is crucial; it simplifies the formalism and means physically that we describe   bulk viscosity on a phenomenological level only, in terms of one single  viscosity  $\zeta$.  We may refer to Velten's paper  \citep{velten13}, on this point, where it is demonstrated that the viscosity term in the energy conservation equation can originate from any of the fluid constituents. In the mentioned paper it is assumed that $\zeta\rightarrow\zeta(\rho_i)$. In the present  paper we do not attribute the viscosity to any specific component but associate it with  the overall fluid $\rho(a)$. We will come back to this in Sect. \ref{Sec:SolWithZetaRho}, where we show that our approach can reproduce the results of Ref.~\citep{velten13}.

\subsection{Obtaining general expressions for E(z)}
In order to see the influence of the viscosity on the evolution of $E(z)$, Wang and Meng \citep{wang14} use the second Friedmann equation \eqref{MCF_Fr2} which contains a pressure term, and which will therefore be affected by the inclusion of viscosity ($p\rightarrow p-\zeta\theta$). As mentioned, they integrate this equation numerically. In the more general case it seems unnecessary to invoke the second Friedmann equation, since  the viscosity modification appears in the expression for $\rho$, Eq.~\eqref{C_Sol_rho_final}, and thus  is already included. In the following,  the first Friedmann equation \eqref{MCF_Fr1} will be used instead. This makes the calculation easier, since no numerics needs be involved.

\subsection{Obtaining general expressions for E(z)}
In order to see the influence of the viscosity on the evolution of $E(z)$, Wang and Meng \citep{wang14} use the second Friedmann equation \eqref{MCF_Fr2} which contains a pressure term, and which will therefore be affected by the inclusion of viscosity ($p\rightarrow p-\zeta\theta$). As mentioned, they integrate this equation numerically. In the more general case it seems unnecessary to invoke the second Friedmann equation, since  the viscosity modification appears in the expression for $\rho$, Eq.~\eqref{C_Sol_rho_final}, and thus  is already included. In the following,  the first Friedmann equation \eqref{MCF_Fr1} will be used instead. This makes the calculation easier, since no numerics needs be involved.

\paragraph*{}Inserting the solution \eqref{C_Sol_rho_final} of the energy  equation into Friedmann's first equation \eqref{MCF_Fr1} and making it all dimensionless by dividing through by $\theta_0^2$  we obtain

\paragraph*{}The generalization is in principle straightforward. One can  calculate the expression  \eqref{C_Ez_zetaRho} for each of the  $n$ components in the multi-component fluid, with different $\zeta(\rho_i)$s in each calculation. Since  \eqref{C_Ez_zetaRho} is the solution of the energy conservation equation, this means that one satisfies  Eq.~\eqref{TiCons} for each component.  Inserting the calculated results in  the first Friedmann equation, one can calculate   the overall evolution of $\theta$ and thus $H$. Since  \eqref{C_Ez_zetaRho} is the solution of the energy conservation equation, this means that one satisfies  Eq.~\eqref{TiCons} for each component.  Inserting the calculated results in  the first Friedmann equation, one can calculate   the overall evolution of $\theta$ and thus $H$. We here used the first option $\zeta(\rho)$ above to illustrate our point, but the argument is equally valid for the second $\zeta(z)$. We finally obtain

nexttext: Here $k_B$ is Boltzmann's constant, $T$ is the temperature and $S$ is the specific entropy. This formula  gives the rate of entropy production in co-moving coordinates for a fluid with energy-momentum tensor equal to the expression \eqref{MCF_EnMomTens}. Our best fit values are all positive; cf. Table \ref{tab:ModelSummary}, but the $95\%$ CIs include negative values. Negative values for $\zeta_0$ have actually been discussed also elsewhere in the  literature; cf., for instance, Ref.~\citep{cardenas15}, where a negative value for  the present day viscosity $\zeta_0$ is found when when discussing a dissipative kinetic k-essence model. The previously considered paper \citep{wang14} also finds the best fit value to be negative for one of the examined  data sets. However, in that paper  a positive value is found to be  mildly favored when all  available information is considered statistically. We may  refer also to Ref.~\citep{brevikgron13} for a review on  universe models with negative bulk viscosity. In that review it is argued  that letting the bulk viscosity take negative values can  be regarded as an assumption  leading  to the same kind of bizarre consequences as the standard approach of letting the equation-of-state parameter $w$ to be less than $-1$. Also, examples are given of examples with negative temperatures; this being relevant through the definition

Effectively, a negative bulk viscosity would mean that the right hand side of the equation above becomes negative instead of the temperature on the left hand side.

\paragraph*{}Though not investigated any further in the present work, let us  as a last issue on this part consider the importance of the interpretation of $\zeta_0$. In Ref.~\citep{brevikstokkan96}, for instance,  matter creation is investigated in a universe with the same energy-momentum tensor as discussed here. Furthermore, it is shown how the entropy production can remain positive even if $\zeta_0$ takes  negative values within a restricted range. This requires that $\zeta_0$ is interpreted as a hydrodynamical kind of particle sink. In that case the particle conservation equation looks different from our case. This leads, as Ref.~\citep{brevikstokkan96} points out, to the same dynamics ($\tensor{T}{^{\mu\nu}_{;\nu}}=0$ give the same equations), but not the same thermodynamics (Eq. \eqref{EntropyProd} is not valid any more). Hence the possibility for negative values of $\zeta_0$.

\paragraph*{}The kind of viscosity that we here consider, originating from lumping two or more components together, may be simplifying though obviously phenomenological.

\paragraph*{}Thus, by changing $w$ for ordinary matter slightly and by including radiation, we see that we can account for $\zeta_0\sim  10^6~$Pa s ($B\sim 1$ km s$^{-1}$Mpc$^{-1}$). Note that the present formalism  holds generally
 for $i$ components, so we are free to bring in any extensions to the basic $\Lambda$CDM model. But we have then to solve more general  integrals.
\paragraph*{}The kind of viscosity that we here consider, originating from lumping two or more components together, may be simplifying though obviously phenomenological.

\section{Conclusion}

The main part of this paper contains a critical survey over solutions of the energy conservation equation for a viscous isotropic Friedmann universe having zero spatial curvature, $k=0$. We
assumed the equation of state in the homogeneous form $p=\sum_i w_i\rho_i$, with $w_i=$ constant for all components in the fluid. With $\rho$ meaning the energy density and $\zeta$ the bulk viscosity we focused on three options: (i) $\zeta=$const, (ii) $\zeta \propto \sqrt{\rho},$ and (iii) $\zeta \propto \rho$. In the theoretical analysis we drew in information from various experimental sources; cf. the   overview of Wang and Meng \cite{wang14} and of  others. Our analysis is kept on a general level, so  that previous
 theories given in Refs.~\cite{wang14} and \cite{velten13}, for instance, can be considered as special cases. This resulted from the fact that our theoretical derivations only assumed a very general multicomponent fluid and therefore had the potential of being applied in very many sub-models, for instance one-component fluid models.


 From the various figures given in this paper it can be  seen that the differences between the various predictions from  the options above are not very large. Even the simple ansatz $\zeta=$constant seems to be justified from a comparison with observational data,
 although we intend to give preference to the case $\zeta \propto \sqrt{\rho}$, which also is a widely accepted model in the cosmological literature.

 As for the magnitude of the bulk viscosity $\zeta_0$ in the present universe we found, on the basis of various sources, that one hardly do better than restricting $\zeta_0$ to lie within an interval. We suggested the interval to extend from $10^4$ to $10^6$ Pa s, although there are some indications that the upper limit could be extended somewhat. In any case, these are several orders of magnitude larger than the bulk viscosities encountered in usual hydrodynamics.

 In Sect. VI we considered the {\it late} universe, extending from $t=0$ onwards. For definiteness we chose the value $\zeta_0= 10^5~$Pa s for the initial (present-day) viscosity. We focused on the occurrence of a big rip singularity in the far future. The numerical values found in the earlier sections enabled us to make a quantitative estimate of the rip time $t_s$. With $\alpha$ defined as $\alpha=w+1$ we found that even the case $\zeta=\zeta_0=$const allows the big rip to occur, if $\alpha$ is negative, i.e., lying in the phantom region. This is the same kind of behavior as found earlier by Caldwell \cite{caldwell03} and others, in the nonviscous case. Of special interest is however the case $\zeta \propto \sqrt{\rho}$, where the fate of the universe is critically dependent on the magnitude of $\alpha$. If $\alpha<0$, the big rip is inevitable, similarly as above. If $\alpha >0$ (the quintessence region), the big rip can actually also occur if $\alpha$ is very small, less than about 0.005. This possibility of sliding through the phantom divide was actually pointed out several years ago \cite{Gorbunova}, but can now be better quantified. Typical rip times are found to lie roughly in the interval from 100 to 200 Gy.

This statement appears to be consistent also with that given  by Zimdahl \citep{zimdahl96}, who investigated this issue in more detail through a different approach.
